awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Pacific Ocean stratification since the last ice age: New constraints from benthic foraminifera
awd_abstract_narration:
Ocean circulation is thought to have played a key role in the transition from the last ice age to the modern interglacial (Earth's most recent "deglaciation"). However, the lack of a mechanistic explanation for the deglaciation represents a major limitation in our understanding of the ocean-climate system. One way to change global temperature is to alter the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere, and there is mounting evidence that at least part of the last deglacial warming was caused by the release of CO2 from the ocean into the atmosphere. A fundamental shift in the ocean's density structure and circulation could have caused such a carbon release, but there are very few deglacial records of physical seawater properties, particularly from the Pacific Ocean, the largest ocean basin. During the course of this project, multiple high-resolution records of seawater temperature and other physical properties from the Southwest Pacific Ocean will be established using geochemical evidence from marine sediment cores. This collaborative work will strengthen ties between the participating universities and provide practical training for graduate and undergraduate students in the sciences. The project's marine records will extend from the last ice age through the present, providing a detailed history of seawater properties that will shed light on the ocean's role in global climate change. 

Colder temperatures and higher salinities of abyssal waters in the Pacific likely both contributed to greater seawater density during the last glacial period. However, temperature values and the vertical temperature structure of the glacial ocean across middle to intermediate depths are unconstrained. The timing of changes in seawater temperature and ventilation across these key depth ranges are also unclear. Determining ocean density structure can help constrain past circulation, and a first step in establishing density is to determine temperature. Three sediment cores (~1100, 1600, and 2500 m water depth) will be used to reconstruct seawater temperature and oxygen isotope composition of seawater (delta18OSW) for the past 30,000 years in the southwest Pacific Ocean at ~250 year resolution. High sediment accumulation rates and well-established, stratigraphically-linked tephra chronologies make the targeted sediment cores from New Zealand's Bay of Plenty particularly valuable for assessing rapid changes in this region. Seawater temperature will be reconstructed using Mg/Ca of benthic foraminiferal calcite (Uvigerina) and then combined with delta18O of benthic calcite from the same species to calculate delta18OSW. At a minimum, delta18OSW acts as a conservative water mass tracer, placing constraints on mixing in the ocean interior. This property may also be used to estimate relative changes in salinity, particularly as more estimates of the past relationship between delta18OSW and salinity become available (e.g., from pore-water studies) ultimately bringing us closer to quantifying density. These records will track the pattern of oceanic warming during the last glacial termination, allowing hypotheses regarding ocean de-stratification to be tested. A suite of 50 core-tops will also be used for ground-truthing and refining the Mg/Ca temperature proxy, providing a region-specific temperature sensitivity if appropriate. The project's results could also improve the research community's ability to characterize glacial circulation. For example, glacial temperature profiles could help constrain the solution of last glacial maximum state estimates, which are very sensitive to Southern Ocean structure.

por.por_cntn:
Variations in the temperature and salinity of seawater drive the ocean's thermohaline circulation, which plays a major role in global climate. Twenty thousand years ago, the Earth was in the grip of an ice age, and then a series of natural events rapidly ended the ice age by warming the planet and melting back the great ice sheets. Ocean circulation likely played a key role in this global climate shift, but our understanding of past ocean properties is incomplete. The lack of a mechanistic explanation for this deglaciation represents a major limitation in our understanding of the ocean-climate system. One way to change global temperature is to alter the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere, and there is mounting evidence that at least part of the last deglacial warming was caused by the release of CO2 from the ocean into the atmosphere. A fundamental shift in the ocean's density structure and circulation could have caused such a carbon release, but until now there have been relatively few deglacial records of physical seawater properties, particularly from the Pacific Ocean, the largest ocean basin.

During this project, multiple high-resolution records of seawater temperature and other physical properties from the Southwest Pacific Ocean were established using geochemical evidence from marine sediment cores. This collaborative work strengthened ties between groups at the University of Maine and Rutgers, the State University of New Jersey, and provided practical training for graduate and undergraduate students in the sciences. The project's novel marine records extend from the last ice age through the present, providing a detailed history of seawater properties that have illuminated the patterns and pacing of past ocean warming.

First, we analyzed a suite of modern sediment samples from the New Zealand region to assess a commonly used tool for reconstructing past ocean temperature: the magnesium to calcium ratio (Mg/Ca) of Uvigerina peregrina, a deep-sea organism that produces a sand-sized calcite shell. Chemical signals locked within these shells can be preserved for thousands, even millions of years, providing clues to past environmental conditions. Our UMaine graduate student analyzed the trace element content of modern U. peregrina shells and compared her results with contemporary ocean conditions (temperature, salinity, etc.). She found that these specimens from the southwest Pacific were behaving similarly to those from other ocean basins and concluded that it is reasonable to apply a single global calibration equation relating ocean temperature and shell Mg/Ca. Uvigerina peregrina Mg/Ca varied as expected with ocean temperature at sites at and above 2 kilometers water depth. However, she also discovered that Mg/Ca of specimens collected between 2.4 - 3.3 km water depth was higher than expected based on the global calibration, pointing to a non-temperature control on Mg incorporation in this species. A specific control parameter could not be definitively identified with the data available, so additional work will be necessary to launch new projects to resolve this question. Identification of the existence of a non-temperature control is an important contribution in itself; details and guidance for paleoceanographers are provided in the graduate student?s first-author article published in the journal Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta.

Determining ocean density structure can help constrain past ocean circulation, and a first step in establishing density is to determine temperature. Three sediment cores collected at ~1100, 1600, and 2500 m water depth in New Zealand's Bay of Plenty were used to reconstruct seawater temperature for the past 30,000 years using Mg/Ca of benthic foraminifera. Our team prepared and analyzed > 500 microfossil samples for trace element analysis and > 150 for stable isotope analyses, augmenting existing stable isotope datasets in the region and providing novel trace element data. At each core site, we were able to generate temperature records from two to three different species of benthic foraminifera. Key outcomes of this work include: 1) All three of these water depths (1100-2500m) warmed by approximately 2˚C between the last ice age and the following interglacial period (the Holocene), 2) Warming initiates at all three depths at approximately 18,000 years ago, and 3) Although the broad pattern of warming is similar in all records, there are some notable differences in temperature estimates derived from different species at the same site, indicating that further work is needed to assess the relative precision and accuracy of the Mg/Ca paleothermometer in multiple species, including Cibicidoides wuellerstorfi and Hoeglundina elegans.

During this project, our team explored ancient oceans and gained valuable skills and experience together. Five undergraduate students learned new laboratory techniques in sedimentology, micropaleontology, and geochemistry; a graduate student earned a masters degree, made progress towards a Ph.D., and published a first-author, peer-reviewed journal article; and two female principal investigators strengthened bonds between groups at different public universities and gained valuable experience that has enhanced their skills as mentors and scientists.
